sentence: Here's your weekly Investing Action Plan: what you need to know as an investor for the coming week.

[ibd-display-video id=2693725 width=50 float=left autostart=true] The holiday-shortened week will feature earnings from a surprising number of highly rated companies, including Salesforce ( CRM ), Analog Devices ( ADI ), Baozun ( BZUN ) and Intuit ( INTU ).
A few key economic indicators are also due, not to mention minutes from the Federal Reserve's last meeting.
Plus, watch retail stocks as Black Friday approaches, after quarterly reports from several big chains offered some hope for brick-and-mortar stores.

With holiday shopping in full swing and Black Friday upon us, your stocks to watch this week are five names looking to buck the gloomy retail trend: Nike ( NKE ), Ross Stores (ROST), Gap (GPS), Shoe Carnival (SCVL) and American Eagle Outfitters (AEO).
Nike on Friday broke out of a cup-with-handle base with a 57.35 buy point, climbing 3.4%, after hiking its dividend late Thursday.
The move also comes as sporting goods retailers Foot Locker (FL) and Hibbett Sports (HIBB) reported smaller-than-feared earnings declines .
But as Nike's fundamental story has come into question over the last few quarters, the stock action has been choppy.
Ross Stores has blasted out of a nearly yearlong consolidation on its quarterly earnings report, with shares up 10% to hit a new all-time high in heavy volume Friday.
The stock remains within the 5% buy range.
Gap got close to clearing a 29.87 buy point from a long cup-with-handle base.
Shares climbed above that level intraday Friday, but pared their gains as 30 is proving to be somewhat of a resistance level.
Shoe Carnival surged 30% Friday, blowing past a 23.85 entry, after reporting strong quarterly numbers late Thursday.
Shares are already well extended from the buy zone.
Although this is a strong move in heavy volume, the 200-day line remains above the 50-day average , signaling weaker performance in recent history.
American Eagle is flying high, up 7%, as peer Abercrombie & Fitch 's (ANF) earnings report impressed .
American Eagle's gain puts the stock past a 14.59 entry.
The 50-day line recently retook the 200-day line, meaning improving performance, but shares remain well below their all-time high reached in 2007.
The leader in software-as-a-service reports Q3 earnings late Tuesday and is expected to report unadjusted EPS of 37 cents, up 54%, with revenue rising 23.5% to $2.65 billion.
At its annual Dreamforce customer conference earlier this month, Salesforce forecast 20%-plus organic revenue growth through 2022 .
The company's cloud software helps businesses organize and handle sales operations and customer relationships.
Shares are extending above buying range after breaking out from a flat base last month.
The chipmaker is scheduled to report fiscal Q4 results before the market open on Tuesday.
Analysts expect the Norwood, Mass.-based company to earn $1.37 a share, up 31% year over year, on sales of $1.5 billion, up 50%.

Last month, analysts at Jefferies raised price targets on Analog Devices along with three other analog chip stocks, citing a profit boost from industry consolidation and long-term demand drivers such as the Internet of Things.
Shares are above buy range after breaking out in September.
Two China-based companies report Q3 results after the market close Tuesday.
The consensus estimate on Baozun, which provides technology that companies use to sell goods online, is for EPS of 8 cents, flat vs. a year ago, on revenue of $131.9 million, up 17%.
The consensus on ZTO (ZTO), a provider of express delivery services in China, is for EPS of 15 cents, also the same as a year ago, on revenue of $454 million, up 29%.
ZTO held its initial public offering one year ago.
Other Chinese companies will report in the coming week, including automotive site BitAuto (BITA) and investment site Noah Holdings (NOAH), both on Monday.
The financial software company perhaps best known for TurboTax and QuickBooks reports fiscal Q1 earnings on Monday.
EPS is expected to fall 17%, to 5 cents, on revenue of $855 million, up 10%.

Zacks cites a variety of factors working in the company's favor: a "huge growth opportunity" in small and medium U.S. business subscribers, its focus on cloud subscriptions, and its moves to grow internationally.
But with growth could come higher expenses.
And much of its business hinges on tax season, and it faces competition from Paycom (PAYC) and ADP (ADP), Zacks said.
Intuit's report also comes as Republicans in Congress push to revamp the tax code, making returns easier to file for millions of taxpayers.
IBD'S TAKE:Bylearning to use call options, investors can significantly reduce risk and capitalize on basing stocks that are making breakaway gains caused by earnings reports.
Minutes from the central bank's Oct. 31-Nov. 1 policy meeting will come out Wednesday.
Fed officials kept rates steady back then and offered no indication that they will veer away from another widely expected rate hike next month.
But the minutes could offer hints on how aggressive policymakers will be next year as inflation remains stubbornly muted.

Sales figures for existing homes will come out Tuesday, when home improvement retailer Lowe's (LOW) reports quarterly results, a week after rival Home Depot (HD) delivered strong earnings and guidance .

A report on durable goods orders is due Wednesday, when a final reading on the University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for November will reveal the state of the shopper as holiday spending takes off.
The maker of PCs and printers reports fiscal Q4 earnings late Tuesday, and analysts expect EPS growth of 22% to 44 cents, with revenue rising 6.5% to $13.33 billion.
At a recent analyst day event, HP (HPQ) said it expects to earn $1.74 to $1.84 a share in fiscal 2018, which starts Nov. 1, topping consensus estimates.

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) also reports fiscal Q4 earnings late Tuesday, and EPS is expected to fall to 28 cents a share vs. 61 cents a year earlier, with revenue down 38% to $7.72 billion, following divestitures of its software and enterprise services businesses.

HPE is battling Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Dell Technologies (DVMT), which acquired data storage systems maker EMC last year, as corporate spending on computer networking and data storage systems slows down.
The deep-discount chain reports Q3 earnings on Tuesday.
Wall Street expects EPS to rise 11% to 90 cents on revenue of $5.282 billion, up 6%.
Dollar Tree (DLTR) has overhauled layouts in its Family Dollar stores, while lower costs and markdowns have helped margins.
Same-store sales have been solid, and so has its e-commerce segment, helped by a post-recession customer who has made a habit of seeking value.
But the company faces tough competition from Wal-Mart (WMT), Dollar General (DG) and European discount chains Aldi and Lidl.
Dollar Tree shares have jumped more than 40% since July.
• Deere (DE) reports Q4 results Wednesday, and analysts expect EPS to jump 58% to $1.42, as revenue grows 22% to $6.91 billion.
The maker of farm and construction equipment has been expanding its global reach and is benefiting from an improved political and economic climate in Latin America that's driving up sales.
• Agilent Technologies (A) releases Q4 results Monday.
Analysts see EPS of 63 cents, up 7%, on revenue of $1.17 billion, up 5%.
The maker of scientific instruments reorganized in 2014, spinning off its electronic division to focus on life sciences and applied chemicals.
• Medtronic (MDT) reports Tuesday, and analysts see fiscal Q2 EPS of 99 cents, down 11.6%, on sales of $6.93 billion, down 5.7%.
Earlier this month, the medical device company said it expects to report sales of $7.05 billion, a 4% decline, driven by divestitures.
